name: designer
content:
designer

noun
 
 
/dɪˈzaɪnə(r)/
 
/dɪˈzaɪnər/
jump to other results
  1. a person whose job is to decide how things such as clothes, furniture, tools, etc. will look or work by making drawings, plans or patterns
    • one of the country's top fashion designers
    • a graphic/web/game designer
    see also interior designer
    Extra Examples
    • She works as a set designer for the Royal Opera House.
    • the company's chief fashion designer
    Topics Clothes and Fashiona2, Jobsa2
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • good
    • talented
    • professional
    • …
    verb + designer
    • bring in
    • hire
    • consult
    • …
    designer + noun
    • clothes
    • fashion
    • handbag
    • …
    See full entry
See designer in the Oxford Advanced American DictionarySee designer in the Oxford Learner's Dictionary of Academic English
Check pronunciation: designer

name: designer
content:
designer

adjective
 
/dɪˈzaɪnə(r)/
 
/dɪˈzaɪnər/
 [only before noun]
jump to other results
  1. made by a famous designer; expensive and having a famous brand name
    • designer clothes
    • designer jeans
    • designer water
    • He had a trendy haircut, an earring and designer stubble (= a short beard, grown for two or three days and thought to look fashionable).
    Collocations Clothes and fashionClothes and fashionClothes
    • be wearing a new outfit/​bright colours/​fancy dress/​fur/​uniform
    • be (dressed) in black/​red/​jeans and a T-shirt/​your best suit/​leather/​silk/​rags (= very old torn clothes)
    • be dressed for work/​school/​dinner/​a special occasion
    • be dressed as a man/​woman/​clown/​pirate
    • wear/​dress in casual/​designer/​second-hand clothes
    • wear jewellery/​accessories/​a watch/​glasses/​contact lenses/​perfume
    • have a cowboy hat/​red dress/​blue suit on
    • put on/​take off your clothes/​coat/​shoes/​helmet
    • pull on/​pull off your coat/​gloves/​socks
    • change into/​get changed into a pair of jeans/​your pyjamas
    Appearance
    • change/​enhance/​improve your appearance
    • create/​get/​have/​give something a new/​contemporary/​retro look
    • brush/​comb/​shampoo/​wash/​blow-dry your hair
    • have/​get a haircut/​your hair cut/​a new hairstyle
    • have/​get a piercing/​your nose pierced
    • have/​get a tattoo/​a tattoo done (on your arm)/a tattoo removed
    • have/​get a makeover/​cosmetic surgery
    • use/​wear/​apply/​put on make-up/​cosmetics
    Fashion
    • follow/​keep up with (the) fashion/​the latest fashions
    • spend/​waste money on designer clothes
    • be fashionably/​stylishly/​well dressed
    • have good/​great/​terrible/​awful taste in clothes
    • update/​revamp your wardrobe
    • be in/​come into/​go out of fashion
    • be (back/​very much) in vogue
    • create a style/​trend/​vogue for something
    • organize/​put on a fashion show
    • show/​unveil a designer’s spring/​summer collection
    • sashay/​strut down the catwalk/(North American English also) runway
    • be on/​do a photo/​fashion shoot
    Topics Clothes and Fashionb1
See designer in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary

name: designer baby
content:
designer baby

noun
 
/dɪˌzaɪnə ˈbeɪbi/
 
/dɪˌzaɪnər ˈbeɪbi/
jump to other results
  1. (used especially in newspapers) a baby that is born from an embryo that was selected from a number of embryos produced using IVF, in order to ensure the baby has or does not have particular genes that can treat or cause disease
See designer baby in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: designer baby

name: designer drug
content:
designer drug

noun
 
/dɪˌzaɪnə ˈdrʌɡ/
 
/dɪˌzaɪnər ˈdrʌɡ/
jump to other results
  1. a drug produced artificially that is designed to have similar effects to an illegal drug
    • a tablet of the designer drug Ecstasy
    Topics Social issuesc2
See designer drug in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: designer drug

name: designer label
content:
designer label

noun
 
/dɪˌzaɪnə ˈleɪbl/
 
/dɪˌzaɪnər ˈleɪbl/
(also label)
jump to other results
  1. the name or trademark of a fashion company
    • He'll only wear clothes with a designer label.
    • Designer labels grew by nearly 4% in 2019.

name: label
content:
label

noun
 OPAL WOPAL S
 
/ˈleɪbl/
 
/ˈleɪbl/
jump to other results
  1. enlarge image
     
     a piece of paper, etc. that is attached to something and that gives information about it synonym tag, ticket
    • Always read the label carefully.
    • price/address labels
    • on a label The washing instructions are on the label.
    Synonyms labellabel
    • tag
    • sticker
    These are all words for a piece of paper, cloth or plastic that is attached to something and gives information about it.
    • label a small piece of paper, cloth or plastic that is attached to something in order to show what it is or give information about it:
      • The washing instructions are on the label.
      • address labels
    • tag (often used in compounds) a small piece of paper, cloth or plastic that is attached to something, or that somebody wears, in order to give information about it/​them:
      • Everyone at the conference had to wear a name tag.
    label or tag?Labels in clothes are usually made of cloth and sewn in. Tags on clothes are usually made of card and cut off before you wear the clothes. A name tag can be stuck or tied onto somebody to show who they are: All babies in the hospital have name tags tied round their ankles. Price tag is much more frequent than price label and is used for both literal and figurative meanings: What does the price tag say? • There is a £20 million price tag on the team’s star player. A label can also be a sticker that you put on an envelope.
    • sticker a sticky label with a picture or message on it, that you stick on to something.
    Patterns
    • a price label/​tag/​sticker
    • to have a label/​tag/​sticker
    • to attach/​put on/​stick on a label/​tag/​sticker
    • The label/​tag/​sticker says…
    see also off-label, own-label
    Extra Examples
    • The label on the bottle listed the ingredients.
    • It doesn't have a price label on it.
    • She stuck labels on all the jars.
    • The care label says ‘dry-clean only’.
    • What does it say on the label?
    • This program produces address labels from your database.
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • adhesive
    • sticky
    • package
    • …
    verb + label
    • bear
    • carry
    • have
    • …
    preposition
    • on a/​the label
    • label on
    See full entry
  2. (disapproving) a word or phrase that is used to describe somebody/something in a way that seems too general, unfair or not correct
    • I hated the label ‘housewife’.
    Extra Examples
    • One sometimes feels that the label ‘classic’ is applied to any book that is dull.
    • Why do we need to attach a label to these feelings?
    • He was cruelly given the label ‘Mr Zero’ by the Press.
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • ideological
    • party
    verb + label
    • apply
    • assign
    • attach
    • …
    See full entry
  3. (also designer label)
     the name or trademark of a fashion company
    • today's major fashion labels
    • She plans to launch her own designer clothes label.
    • He's really fashion-conscious and will only wear labels (= clothes with a designer label).
    see also white labelTopics Clothes and Fashionb1
  4. a company that produces and sells music, CDs, etc.
    • the Virgin record label
    • It's his first release for a major label.
    Extra Examples
    • The band is hoping to sign with a major label.
    • The record was produced under the Virgin label.
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • music
    • record
    • major
    • …
    verb + label
    • launch
    • sign to
    • sign with
    • …
    preposition
    • under a/​the label
    See full entry
    5. Word OriginMiddle English (denoting a narrow strip): from Old French, ‘ribbon’.
